If a sentient being wishes to enter the womb, if the conditions are complete they will receive a body, if not complete they will not receive a body.
What is meant by conditions not being complete?

Namely, if the parents give rise to lustful thoughts, and the intermediate state being appears before them seeking a place to be reborn, but these parents' red and white elements either come before or after and are not simultaneous, and there are various illnesses in their bodies, then it will not enter the womb.

If the mother's womb is afflicted with wind, bile, blood, or qi blockage, or if the fetus is blocked, or if there is a knot of flesh, or if there is a salty disease, a wheat belly disease, an ant waist disease, a camel mouth, a bent wood of a chariot yoke, a chariot axle, a chariot hub, a tree leaf, a twisted vine shoot, a fetus like wheat awns, or if the essence and blood leak out and do not temporarily stay, or if the fetus is stuck in the lower water, or if the fetus's path is rough, or if it is sharp above and below, or crooked, shallow, or leaky, or high, low, or short, or if there are various diseases, then one cannot enter the womb.

If the parents are noble and have great blessings and virtues, while the intermediate existence is lowly, or if the intermediate existence is noble and has great blessings and virtues, while the parents are lowly, or if both have blessings and virtues but do not have a corresponding karmic affinity, then one also does not receive the womb.
In this way, the intermediate existence, when about to enter the womb, first gives rise to two kinds of inverted thoughts.
What are the two?
Namely, when the parents are united, if it is a male, it gives rise to love for the mother and hatred for the father, thinking that the semen flowing from the father is its own.
If it is a female, it gives rise to love for the father and hatred for the mother, thinking that the blood flowing from the mother is its own.
If it does not give rise to this hatred and love, then it will not enter the womb.
Furthermore, Ananda!
How does one enter the mother's womb?

Namely, when the parents give rise to thoughts of lust and desire, when the menstrual cycle is in harmony, and when the intermediate existence appears before them, without the many faults mentioned above, and when the karmic conditions are complete, one can then enter the womb.
In this way, when the intermediate existence is about to enter the womb, there are two kinds.
What are the two?
First, lacking merit and virtue; second, possessing great merit and virtue.
Those without merit will give rise to thoughts of discernment, and what they see will lead them to think:
'Now I have encountered wind, cold, rain, and a large crowd of people, and the crowd's power is pressing in on me.'
They will then give rise to fear.
'I should now enter a grass hut or leaf hut, or hide by the roots of a wall, or go into the mountains, marshes, forests, or dens.'
They will further give rise to various thoughts, and according to what they see, they will enter their mother's womb.
Those with great merit will also think:
'Now I have encountered wind, cold, rain, and a large crowd of people, and the crowd's power is pressing in on me.'

They will also give rise to fear, and will immediately go up to a high building or a large pavilion, or enter a palace hall or bed, and will also give rise to various other thoughts, and according to what they see, they will enter their mother's womb. The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
In this way, the intermediate existence first enters the womb and is called kalala. It obtains the body by relying on the impurity of the parents and past karma.
Such karma and the parents' various conditions each do not arise by themselves, but because of the power of their combination, one then receives the body.

It is like using a vessel to contain curds, a person, rope, etc., and then whey is produced. Among the various conditions, it cannot be obtained, but because of the power of their combination, the whey is then able to be produced.
The body of kalala is also like this. Because of the power of causes and conditions, it is then able to enter the womb.

It is like relying on green grass, cow dung, and jujube curds to each produce worms. In each of them, the worms cannot be obtained. Because of the power of causes and conditions, the worms are then able to be born.
When these worms are born, they are blue, yellow, red, and white, each taking on the color of what they rely on.

Therefore, you should know that this body is born from the impure substances of the parents. If you search for it among the various conditions, it cannot be found, and yet it is not apart from the conditions. Due to the power of their combination, one then receives the embryo.

When this body is born, it and the four great elements of the parents have no distinction in nature. Namely, earth is the nature of solidity, water is the nature of wetness, fire is the nature of heat, and wind is the nature of movement.
If the body in the kalala stage only had the earth element and no water element, it would be like someone grasping dry flour and ash, which would never combine.
If it only had the water element and no earth element, it would be like oil and water, whose nature is slippery and without solidity, and would then flow and scatter.
If it only had earth and water and no fire element, it would be like a lump of meat in a shady place during the summer months, which would then rot and decay without the illumination of sunlight.

Only earth, water, and fire, without the wind element, will not grow. It is like a person and his disciple who are skilled in cooking sugar, and whatever they make, they make sure to leave it hollow inside. If there is no wind power, it will never succeed.

In this way, the four great elements mutually rely on and support each other to be established. Therefore, you should know that the body of the kalala, which is born from the four great elements of the parents' karma and wind, is also like this. It cannot be obtained in the midst of the many conditions, but because of the power of combination, it then receives a body.

In the second seven-day period, when the body is in the mother's womb, the karmic wind that it induces is called pervasive.

That wind gently blows on the mother's left and right sides, causing the kalala body's appearance to gradually manifest, resembling thick curd or coagulated butter. Internally boiled by heat, it then transforms into the arbuda body, and the four elements are gradually perfected.
In the third seven-day period, when the body is in the mother's womb, it again induces a karmic wind called the mouth of the womb.

In the womb, the internal heat boils it, and the four elements gradually increase.
In the fourth week, when the fetus is in the mother's womb, it again experiences a karmic wind called grasping.

First, the gathering of various illnesses in the body is called internal suffering. Second, being oppressed by humans and non-humans is called external suffering.
What is meant by the gathering of various illnesses in the body?

Namely, illnesses arise in the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, throat, teeth, chest, abdomen, hands, and feet, or else wind, epilepsy, runny nose, phlegm, insanity, consumption, asthma, cough, frequent urination, scabies, leprosy, boils, ulcers, emaciation, hemorrhoids, fistula, evil sores, pus, blood, chills, and fevers - various illnesses all gather in this body.
There are also 101 diseases of the heart, 101 diseases of the gall, 101 diseases of the wind, and 101 diseases of phlegm. The combination of wind, gall, and phlegm also gives rise to 101 diseases.
Such 404 illnesses afflicting the body are called internal suffering.
There is also external suffering that harms this body, namely, being in prison, beaten, whipped, fettered, shackled, bound, or having one's ears, nose, hands, feet, or head cut off.
They are not protected by the gods, and non-humans, evil ghosts, spirits, yakshas, and rakshasas take advantage of them.
They are also bitten by poisonous insects such as mosquitoes, bees, and so forth. Cold, heat, hunger, thirst, wind, rain, and other kinds of suffering afflict their bodies.
This is so even among humans, let alone the sufferings of the evil realms, which are difficult to describe in detail.
Therefore, one should know that all this is due to the retribution of unwholesome karma from the past.

If one is harmed by swords and sticks, one builds city walls and moats to defend one's body. For evil winds, rain, mosquitoes, bees, and stings, one seeks shelter. For the four hundred and four internal and external sufferings of illness, one seeks food, drink, bedding, medicine, fields, gardens, houses, gold, silver, the seven treasures, servants, carriages, and other necessities to supply one's needs. If one's mind is not satisfied, one gives rise to suffering and distress;
Even if one obtains precious wealth, one is stingy and always guards it. If it is lost, one gives rise to great suffering.

This five-aggregates body, in each and every posture, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, is all suffering.
If one walks for a long time without resting for a moment, that is called suffering. Standing, sitting, and lying down for long periods of time are also all suffering.
If, after walking for a long time, one gets to rest for a while, one gives rise to the thought of pleasure, but in reality it is not pleasure.

If, after standing for a long time, one gets to sit for a while, or if, after sitting for a long time, one gets to lie down for a while, one gives rise to the thought of pleasure, but in reality there is no pleasure.
Therefore, you should know that this five-aggregates body is all called suffering.

If there are people who, for their own benefit, for the benefit of others, or for the benefit of both self and others, should be disgusted with such sufferings, leave the household life to cultivate and study, then the Dharma of liberation and nirvana will not be wasted.
If there are people who offer them clothing, bedding, medicine, and necessities for life, they will obtain great rewards, majestic virtue, and fame.
